Award.AwardTitle: Noyce Phase II: Program for the Recruitment of Mathematics and Science Teachers (PROMSE)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This four-year Phase II scholarship and stipend project is building on a previous four-year Phase I project. Ten two-year $20,000 scholarships are being awarded to undergraduates majoring in mathematics or one of the sciences entering a single subject credential teacher preparation program, and twenty $10,000 one-year stipends to post-baccalaureate STEM professionals undertaking teacher certification studies. An emphasis is being placed on the recruitment of students interested in teaching one of the physical sciences.

Monitoring and evaluation of the Phase I outcomes is being expanded and extended. Longitudinal data will be collected for a minimum of the initial five years of the Noyce scholar's teaching career. The overall goals of the evaluation are to track, describe and assess the progress of the scholars and success as they fulfill their teaching service obligations, analyze the effectiveness of the Noyce program, and support data-driven decisions to strengthen the program and its outcomes over time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CSU, Fresno PROMSE - Noyce II

 The Noyce II project at Fresno State known as the Program for Recruitment of Mathematics and Science Educators (PROMSE) was implemented beginning in 2007 with goals to recruit, retain and prepare outstanding future science and mathematics teachers for high needs classrooms of California’s Central Valley. PROMSE has supported 30 Noyce Scholars of which 22 are now currently teaching in a high needs classroom in the Central Valley or beyond.

 

PROMSE has been a keystone in  efforts to increase the number of secondary school teachers credentialed in the sciences and mathematics.  In 2005-2006,  among the 23 campuses in the California State University system CSU Fresno was 17th in the number of science and math credentials produced, with 25.  By the 2010-2011 academic year, CSU Fresno produced 92 science and math credentials, 5th in the system and exceeded only by campuses in the Los Angeles area (data available from http://csufresno.edu/teachmathscience

 

PROMSE has not only increased the quantity of STEM teachers, it has increased the quality and diversity. The average grade point average for our PROMSE Scholars is 3.52. Over 50% have a gpa of 3.7 or higher. Forty percent are males and 60% are female. Seven percent of our Scholars/Teachers are African-American, 17% are of Asian descent, 57% are Caucasian, and 20% are Hispanic. Nearly half of our PROMSE are first time college goers. Scholars have majors in one of the sciences or in mathematics and several of our science Scholars are authorized to teach in more than one science discipline.

 

PROMSE has, over its five year operation period, provided special counseling and advising for the Scholars and has also provided an array of support programs and activities designed to help Scholars achieve excellence in the classroom. Two of the more important components of the Noyce programs at Fresno State that we feel are responsible for the program’s successes are 1.) the comprehensive early field experience program and 2.) the summer science research opportunities.  The early field experience is designed so that Scholars as undergraduates are placed in a high need school with a specially selected mentor teacher for up to 28 weeks for 8-10 hours per week. Scholars begin their experience as early as their sophomore year and are strongly encouraged to maintain their experience through their senior year, right up until they are ready to enter the credential program. Under this program, the Scholar is identified as a teaching assistant and helps students in the classroom with one-on-one or small group instruction. The early field experience gives Scholars a chance, early in their preparation for the teaching profession, to work with children and observe a range of teaching and classroom management styles. Once Scholars are ready to begin the credential program, we strategically place them with a former Mentor Teacher as their Master Teacher for initial student teaching or first semester of student teaching; therefore, making a smooth transition from undergraduate to student teacher. By using this strategy, student teachers are instructing from day one rather than waiting to establish a rapport before teaching. We have seen that as a result of this program Scholars are much more prepared for the classroom when they enter the student teaching phase of the credential program.
